title: Conference Opening with organizers
abstract: Join neuromatch 2.0 conference opening with Konrad Kording (UPenn), Dan Goodman (Imperial), Brad Wyble (Penn State), Tim Vogels (Oxford), Chris Rozell (Georgia Tech), Yiota Poirazi (IMBB/FORTH)

title: Reconstructing sound source location in auditory cortex
abstract: The spatial location of a sound source must be reconstructed from sound localization cues, principally available through the comparison of the timing and level of the sound at the two ears. While nuclei in thebrainstem are responsible for extracting these cues, one of the mostconsistent consequences of auditory cortical inactivation in mammals isan impairment in sound localization. What role, then, does auditorycortex play in this process? We asked whether primary auditory corticalneurons represent sound localization cues, or locations of sound in theworld. When recording from freely moving ferrets performing a soundlocalisation task some neurons only encoded low frequency timing cues,or high frequency level cues, many cortical neurons encoded location inspace across sound localization cue types. Next, we asked whatcoordinate frame neurons in auditory cortex represented auditory space.Since auditory space is reconstructed from a comparison of signals atthe two ears, spatial receptive fields have long been assumed to beanchored to the direction of the head. However, all previous recordingshave been made in animals whose heads are fixed or maintained at the center of a speaking ring, leaving this assumption untested. We recordedspatial receptive fields in animals foraging freely through a soundfield and observed that while many neurons did encode auditory space ina head centered reference frame, a smaller subpopulation encoded thelocation of the source in the world. Both of these findings areconsistent with auditory cortex playing a key role in the construction of auditory objects that are defined by their identity and location inthe world.

title: The role of "learning" vs innate mechanisms in AI
abstract: The debate between  Timothy Lillicrap and Anthony Zador on his recent paper: "A critique of pure learning and what artificial neural networks can learn from animal brains" (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-019-11786-6)
fullname: Debate: Anthony Zador (Cold Spring Harbor) vs. Timothy Lillicrap (Google DeepMind)

abstract: Join us for an open mic social hour on Crowdcast where we ask attendess on stage to dance, sing, tell jokes, show off their toddler, etc. A sign-up sheet will be available for registered attendees.

title: Neuronal regulation of immunity: Why, how and where?
abstract: The philosophical mind-body problem examines the relationship between the mind, a mental process, and its impact on the body, a physical entity. Such interactions are manifested in modern medicine by the emergence of disease following stress, or recovery in response to placebo treatment. Nevertheless, this fundamental aspect of physiology remains largely unexplored. In this talk I will focus on a specific aspect of brain-body interactions, the dialog between the brain and the immune system, the body’s main protection mechanism. I will demonstrate mechanisms whereby these two systems can work in coordination, how the brain detects immune activity and how specific brain activity can orchestrate immune response to cancer and gut inflammation.

title: Differential Resilience of Neurons and Networks to Perturbation
abstract: Both computational and experimental results in single neurons and small networks demonstrate that very similar network function can result from quite disparate sets of neuronal and network parameters. Using the crustacean stomatogastric nervous system, we now study the influence of these differences in underlying structure on differential resilience of individuals to a variety of environmental perturbations, including changes in temperature, pH, potassium concentration and neuromodulation.  We show that neurons with many different kinds of ion channels can smoothly move through different mechanisms in generating their activity patterns, thus extending their dynamic range.

title: Connectomes across development reveal brain-wide synaptic rewiring in C. elegans
abstract: From birth to adulthood, an animal's nervous system changes as its body grows and its behaviours mature. However, the extent of circuit remodeling across the connectome is poorly understood. Here, we used serial-section electron microscopy to reconstruct the brain of eight isogenic C. elegans individuals at different ages to learn how an entire wiring diagram changes with maturation. We found that the overall geometry of the nervous system is preserved from birth to adulthood, establishing a constant scaffold upon which synaptic change is built. We observed substantial connectivity differences among individuals that make each brain partly unique. We also observed developmental connectivity changes that are consistent between animals but different among neurons, altering the strengths of existing connections and creating additional connections. Collective synaptic changes alter information processing of the brain. Across maturation, the decision-making circuitry is maintained whereas sensory and motor pathways are substantially remodelled, and the brain becomes progressively more modular and feedforward. These synaptic changes reveal principles by which maturation shapes brain and behavior across development.

title: Revealing the multidimensional mental representations of natural objects
abstract: Our mental representations of objects are assumed to be characterized according to numerous object dimensions (e.g. animacy, shape, color, function). While several such dimensions have been suggested to govern our similarity judgments and behavior, we are still lacking a comprehensive description of the core dimensions that allow us to accurately generate these mental representations. Here we developed a computational model of object similarity for images of 1,854 natural objects based on crowdsourcing 1.46 million triplet odd-one-out similarity judgments. This model captured most explainable variance in behavior and pairwise object similarity and produced 49 highly reproducible and interpretable object dimensions reflecting both perceptual and conceptual properties of those objects. The dimensions predicted external behavior such as category membership and typicality judgments, suggesting that the identified dimensions generalize to behavior beyond the specific task. Importantly, when exposing participants to those dimensions, they were able to assign dimension values to new objects that allowed accurate reconstruction of object similarity, opening up the pathway towards a generative model of object similarity. Together, these results reveal a low-dimensional, interpretable representational embedding that accurately captures human similarity judgments for thousands of objects.

title: Training deep neural density estimators to identify mechanistic models of neural dynamics
abstract: Mechanistic modeling in neuroscience aims to explain observed phenomena in terms of underlying causes. However, determining which model parameters agree with complex and stochastic neural data presents a significant challenge. We address this challenge with a machine learning tool which uses deep neural density estimators— trained using model simulations— to carry out Bayesian inference and retrieve the full space of parameters compatible with raw data or selected data features. Our method is scalable in parameters and data features, and can rapidly analyze new data after initial training. We demonstrate the power and flexibility of our approach on receptive fields, ion channels, and Hodgkin–Huxley models. We also characterize the space of circuit configurations giving rise to rhythmic activity in the crustacean stomatogastric ganglion, and use these results to derive hypotheses for underlying compensation mechanisms. Our approach will help close the gap between data-driven and theory-driven models of neural dynamics.

title: Burst-dependent synaptic plasticity can coordinate learning in hierarchical circuits
abstract: Synaptic plasticity is believed to be a key physiological mechanism for learning. It is well-established that it depends on pre and postsynapticactivity. However, models that rely solely on pre and postsynapticactivity for synaptic changes have, to date, not been able to accountfor learning complex tasks that demand hierarchical networks. Here, weshow that if synaptic plasticity is regulated by high-frequency burstsof spikes, then neurons higher in the hierarchy can coordinate theplasticity of lower-level connections. Using simulations andmathematical analyses, we demonstrate that, when paired with short-termsynaptic dynamics, regenerative activity in the apical dendrites, andsynaptic plasticity in feedback pathways, a burst-dependent learningrule can solve challenging tasks that require deep networkarchitectures. Our results demonstrate that well-known properties ofdendrites, synapses, and synaptic plasticity are sufficient to enablesophisticated learning in hierarchical circuits.

title: Recursive cortical network: A generative vision model with deep grounding in neuroscience.
abstract:
Modern deep neural networks resemble the feed-forward hierarchy of simple and complex cells in the neocortex. Neuroscience has postulated computational roles for lateral and feedback connections, segregated contour and surface representations, and border-ownership coding observed in the visual cortex, yet these features are not commonly used by deep neural networks. Recursive cortical network (RCN) is a new computational model that systematically incorporates these neuroscience findings into its representational structure, and inference algorithms. We show that this leads to orders of magnitude improvements in data-efficiency and generalization on many standard AI benchmarks, which are important for the next frontier of AI algorithms. 

We discuss how these neuroscience observations are not hacks, but general principles that deep models will have to incorporate for better data efficiency. For instance, factorization of contours and appearance, is intertwined with the general properties of smoothness of natural signals. Border-ownership signaling is important when shape is represented in a hierarchical manner. Lateral connections work in coordination with pooling to encode shape in an invariant manner while preserving specificity. Understanding how these disparate observations combine together into a coherent representational structure is one of the problems being tackled by RCN. 

In this work we will show that RCN, by virtue of capturing the causal semantics of image generation, is more robust to clutter and adversarial images compared to standard deep NNs.  As a generative model, RCN outperforms neural network models when tested on noisy and cluttered examples and generated realistic samples from one-shot training of handwritten characters. We will show that this performance translates to real-world scenarios and demonstrate how RCN improves the efficiency or robot picking in cluttered factory environments. 

In contrast to current deep generative models, RCN can be flexibly queried: it can answer queries it was not trained on. We emonstrate how this property is important for occlusion reasoning and amodal completion, and show that RCN outperforms deep convolutional networks on these tasks. Using two benchmark datasets based on real-world objects and MNIST digits, we show that RCN can recognize digits and objects which require inferring subjective contours, and show that its performance matches human psychophysics in dealing with occlusions.

Moreover, by mapping the graphical model computations to known cortical anatomy and physiology, we demonstrate how the graphical model of RCN can make precise predictions about visual cortical microcircuits, and simulate the cortical dynamics of subjective contour effects, and neon color spreading. 

Our work demonstrates that structured probabilistic models that incorporate inductive biases from neuroscience can lead to robust, generalizable machine learning models that learn with high data efficiency. It can trigger discussions that are highly relevant for this conference : inductive biases, representation of prior knowledge, robust generalization,  flexible inference, and AI models that are deeply grounded in neuroscience.

title: Spatial maps in piriform cortex during olfactory navigation
abstract: Animals rely on chemical signals to forage for food, shelter, and mates. Such behaviors call for odor cues to be linked to locations within their environment. Nonetheless, where and how this happens in the brain is not known. Here, we show that spatial and olfactory information converge in posterior piriform cortex (pPCx), an olfactory region with strong associative circuity. Ensembles of pPCx neurons recorded in rats performing an odor-cued spatial navigation task were robustly selective for both odor identity and spatial location, forming an olfactory space map. Spatially-selective pPCx neurons displayed joint selectivity for odors, stability across behavioral contexts and functional coupling to the hippocampal theta rhythm. These results implicate the pPCx as a strong candidate region to associate spatial and olfactory information in support of navigational behavior.

title: Larger GPU-accelerated brain simulations with procedural connectivity
Adaptive behaviour: coding of past and present events in prefrontal cortex during learning.
Processing of visual and tactile object information in the fronto-parietal grasping network
abstract:
When we are using our hands to interact with our surroundings, many different brain areas are involved in the sensory-motor transformation required to link sensory information to meaningful actions. While we have some understanding about the role of individual brain areas in this process, less is known about the way different brain areas interact during grasp planning.
To investigate how information from different senses is used in the process of grasp-planning, we recorded multi-channel spiking activity from a rhesus macaque (Macaca mulatta) while he performed a delayed-grasping task. The animal was trained to grasp six different objects that he has perceived beforehand either visually or tactually. To better understand the underlying sensory-motor transformation in preparation of this action, spiking activity was recorded from primary motor cortex, premotor cortex and the primary somatosensory cortex. 
By comparing the firing rates of single- and multi-units from these cortical areas, we identified specific differences in the brain activity between the two task conditions, even though the executed movement was identical. Specifically in the preparatory activity, after the object was seen or touched but before the object was lifted, up to 20% of units showed significant tuning differences between the two sensory modalities, i.e., in the way the grasps were planned based on visual vs. tactile object information. To better quantify the difference between visual and tactile grasp planning, we trained a classifier on the recorded data to predict the sensory modality as well as the grasping action, and this classifier was able to decode the sensory condition during the memory period well above chance. 
Together we could demonstrate significant differences in the way visual and tactile object information is processed in these brain areas, while the resulting movement was identical in both conditions. This demonstrates a significant role not only of object information, but also of the sensory modality conveying this information, for the preparation of upcoming grasp movements.

Supported by: Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (SFB 889, Project C09).

title: Empirically Constrained Network Models for Contrast-dependent Modulation of Gamma Rhythm in V1
abstract: Here we present experimentally-validated computational models of gamma rhythm and use these to investigate gamma oscillation instability. To this end, we extracted empirical constraints for PING (Pyramidal Interneuron Network Gamma) models from monkey single-unit and LFP responses recorded during contrast variation. These constraints implied weak rather than strong PING, connectivity between excitatory (E) and inhibitory (I) cells within specific bounds, and input strength variations that modulated E but not I cells. Constrained models showed valid behaviours, including gamma frequency increases with contrast and power saturation or decay at high contrasts. The route to gamma instability involved increased heterogeneity of E cells with increasing input triggering a breakdown of I cell pacemaker function. We illustrate the model’s capacity to resolve disputes in the literature. Our work is relevant for the range of cognitive operations to which gamma oscillations contribute and could serve as a basis for future, more complex models.

title: Visuomotor mechanisms of flexible control of walking stability in Drosophila
abstract: Locomotion performance depends on a precise knowledge of the speed and configuration of the moving body. Such an internal estimate of self-motion is fundamental to control the coordinated action of eyes, head and limbs as animals explore and acquire information from their environment. We are interested in understanding how this information emerges in sensorimotor circuits and is used to control movement in a behavioral goal-specific manner. In this talk, I will focus on a canonical visuomotor network in the fly whose function is thought to contribute to one conserved principle of locomotion— stability. Through analysis of behavior in simultaneous with recordings of neural activity, I will describe that this network combines multimodal signals to control locomotion performance in a moment-by-moment flexible manner guided by the behavioral goal of the fly.

title: The usefulness of Bayesian models
abstract: This debate between Alex Pouget and Brad Love is inspired by the published exchange that followed the paper "Bayesian Just-So Stories in Psychology and Neuroscience" by Bowers and Davis in 2012. It will explore the usefulness of Bayesian models for capturing neural and behavioral findings, including how the thinking on this topic has evolved in the intervening years.
fullname: Debate: Alex Pouget (Geneva) and Brad Love (UCL)

title: Chloride ion dynamics in the nervous system
abstract: Fast inhibitory synaptic inhibition is critical for shaping the functional properties of neuronal networks. At a receptor level, synaptic inhibition is mediated by type A g-aminobutyric acid receptors (GABAARs), which are primarily permeable to chloride (Cl-) ions. ﻿Therefore, the transmembrane gradient for Cl- sets the driving force for Cl-flux across these receptors, controlling the properties of inhibitory synaptic signaling. In this talk I will: 1) explore what establishes the driving force for Cl- in neurons, 2) show how the transmembrane Cl- gradient can change during activity thereby modifying the input-output properties of neurons and 3) discuss how Cl- dynamics are critical for understanding and treating epileptic seizures.

title: Latent causes, prediction errors, and the organization of memory
abstract:
In recent years, my lab has suggested that incoming information is parsed into separate clusters ("states" in reinforcement learning parlance) -- all events that are assigned to one cluster are learned about together, whereas events in different clusters do not interfere with each other in learning. Moreover, we have suggested that prediction errors are key to this separation into clusters. In this talk, I will revisit these ideas building not only on behavioral experiments showing evidence for clustering, but also experiments that show the effects of prediction errors on episodic memory. I will attempt to tie the different findings together into a hypothesis about how prediction errors affect not only learning, but also the organization of memory.

(Work with Sam Gershman, Angela Radulescu and Nina Rouhani)

title: Group matching (or social hour)
abstract: An hour slot for attendees who signed up for group mind-matching to chat and socialze. Attendees who signed up should organize via email with their matches to create a meeting session to chat during this hour. Those who didn't can stay on Crowdcast or head to Mozilla Hubs for social hour.

title: Neural control of movement in Hydra
abstract: Hydra is a fascinating model organism for neuroscience. It is transparent; new genetic lines allow one to image activity in both neurons (Dupre and Yuste, 2017) and muscle cells (Szymanski and Yuste, 2019) ; it exhibits rich behavior; and it continually rebuilds itself. Hydra’s fairly simply physical structure as a two-layered fluid-filled hydrostat and the accessibility of information about neural and muscle activity opens the possibility of a complete model of neural control of behavior. We will discuss development of biophysical models of the nerve net and muscle cell layers and the actuation of a biomechanical model of the body column.

title: Magnetic Nanotransducers for Wireless Neuromodulation
abstract: Ion channels offer direct means to manipulating neural activity with specificity and temporal precision. The nanometer dimensions of these molecular machines inspire the design of neuromodulation tools operating at comparable spatial scales. In this talk I will discuss how magnetic nanotransducers based on synthetic magnetic materials can be applied to convert external weak magnetic fields into stimuli, such as heat, force, torque, pH change, and chemicals, commonly perceived by ion channels. I will illustrate the importance of magnetic properties in controlling magnetically-mediated neuronal modulation in the context of ion influxes and rodent behavior. This talk will also highlight opportunities offered by wireless neuromodulation in behavioral and systems neuroscience. Finally, I will touch on future possibilities for preclinical and translational applications of nanotransducer-mediated wireless magnetic neuromodulation.

title: Growing up in Science
abstract: Growing up in Science (www.growingupinscience.com) is a mentorship series that started at NYU but has spread to many other places. In it, faculty members and other guests describe their life and career story with an emphasis on struggles, failures, detours, and doubts. In this seminar, Wei Ji Ma will briefly describe the series and explain how you can start your own. Then, Anne Churchland and Wei Ji Ma will tell their own stories.
fullname: Growing Up in Science: a panel with Wei Ji Ma (NYU) and Anne Churchland (Cold Spring Harbor)

title: Impact of single neurons in cortical circuits with dense and strong connectivity
abstract:
Experimental studies have shown that individual neurons can impact the activity of their local network. Recent evidence in the reptilian cortex shows that just one spike can trigger repeatable cascades of activity in the surrounding neurons (Hemberger et al. 2019). Similar sequences of neuronal activations have been reported in other systems, such as mammalian cortex and the birdsong system, but we still lack a good mechanistic understanding. To study how single spikes impact local activity, we built a computational model of the three-layered turtle cortex. We found that the model, fitted to experimental data and with minimal assumptions about the connectivity, was able to reproduce sequences from single spikes comparable to those observed ex vivo.

The model included rare but powerful synapses from a long-tailed distribution as reported experimentally. By simulating alternative models where the distribution is truncated, we showed that these strong connections are the main conduit through which individual excitatory neurons most reliably influence their local network. Activity in the responding network evolves by spreading away from the activated neuron and is sensitive to the global level of activity. Contrary to excitatory cells, we found that inhibitory neurons quickly lose the temporal precision of their response when background network activity increased. Therefore, we predict the presence of repeatable sequences of excitatory but not inhibitory spikes in vivo. Finally, by studying the connections most frequently traversed and quantifying the motifs that are present, we describe how these strong connections are supported by an abundance of weak ones. Our work zooms into the fine network interactions triggered by a single spike of a single neuron in cortex, and explains how repeatable and temporally precise sequences of activity can be generated, with ample implications for information transmission in cortical networks.

title: Parallel Systems for Sound Processing and Functional Connectivity among Layer 5 and 6 Auditory Corticothalamic Projection Neurons
abstract:
Corticofugal neurons in the deep layers of the auditory cortex (ACtx) innervate a wide range of targets both within and outside the central auditory pathway. Of the different corticofugal systems, the corticothalamic (CT) projection is the largest. Layer (L) 5 and L6 CT neurons exhibit markedly different morphological, intrinsic, and synaptic properties, suggesting that they comprise two parallel projection systems from the cortex to the thalamus. Until now, technical limitations have made it impossible to extend these observations to sensory processing in awake animals. Here, we leveraged recent advances in multi-channel electrophysiology and optogenetics to make targeted recordings from both layer 5 (L5 CT) and 6 (L6 CT) corticothalamic neurons in awake mice.
As a first step towards highlighting the differences in anatomical connectivity of L5 and L6 CT neurons, we used an intersectional viral strategy to label each cell type. While L6 CT neurons primarily targeted the ventral subdivision of the medial geniculate body (MGB), L5 CT neurons had more divergent connectivity, with collateral axons innervating the non-lemniscal regions of the MGB en route to the inferior colliculus. To characterize the sensory processing capabilities of these neurons, we developed an antidromic optogenetic “phototagging” approach to isolate individual L5 CT and L6 CT units on high-density multichannel probes in awake, head-fixed mice. L6 CT neurons exhibited shorter response latencies, narrower frequency tuning, and sparser stimulus selectivity than L6 CT neurons. Linear spectrotemporal receptive field (STRF) fits explained a higher percentage of response variance in L6 CT neurons, indicating a higher degree of linearity. The amount of additional variability that was explained when the nonlinear effects of acoustic context were modelled was larger in L5 CT neurons, suggesting a greater susceptibility to contextual nonlinearities. Analyses of functional connectivity revealed that L6 CT neurons powerfully regulate response gain across the deep layers of the ACtx via dense local connections with inhibitory subnetworks, while L5 CT neurons featured far weaker feedforward excitation onto local columnar neurons.
Collectively, these findings suggest a dichotomy of sensory processing and functional connectivity in two corticothalamic cell-types. L6 CTs show sparse stimulus selectivity but can powerfully regulate the gain on local cortical processing, whereas L5 CTs integrate local circuit processing with dense, non-linear coding and “broadcast” signals out of the ACtx. Future work will entail recording from these projection neurons during task engagement to establish how these functional differences are adaptively used in service of goal-directed behavior.

title: Sparse Coding, Interpretable ReLU Auto-encoders, and Pattern Discovery in Neural Data
abstract: An important problem in neuroscience is to identify recurrent patterns that occur  in time-series data, in an unsupervised fashion. Spike sorting, as well as the  identification of spikes from Calcium imaging data, are two examples of this problem  in which the data are real-valued. The identification of recurrent patterns from spiking  data is an example in which the data are binary or count valued. I cast these problems  as one of learning a convolutional dictionary, subject to sparsity constraints, from  data drawn according to a natural exponential family. I propose two general approaches  towards its solution. The first approach is reminiscent of the algorithm for classical  convolutional dictionary learning, which alternates between sparse coding and dictionary  update steps. The second approach utilizes a novel class of ReLU convoltuional  auto-encoders obtained by unrolling/unfolding the sparse coding and dictionary update  steps of the former. Unlike the first approach, it can be implemented on GPUs, making it  faster and amenable to larger data sets. Moreover, it gives a principled prescription for  building interpretable neural networks for data from the natural exponential family. I will  show applications to spike sorting and to the problem of automatically learning the  stimulus effect from neural spiking data acquired in the barrel cortex of mice in response  to periodic whisker deflections.

title: Human Brain Spatio-Temporal Maps of Perception
abstract: The human brain is a time machine: we are constantly remembering our past, and projecting ourselves in the future.  Neuroscientists are explorers who study how this neural time machine works, how to repair it when it is damaged, and how to improve it.  In this talk, I will present results from a neuroimaging technique that combines MEG (magneto-encephalography) signals with fMRI (functional magnetic resonance imaging) to unravel the spatiotemporal dynamics of visual and auditory perception, at the scale of the whole human brain. This fusion approach is well suited for developing functional biomarkers to aid clinicians in diagnosing disorders, pinpointing impairments as a precursor to therapeutic interventions, as well as studying how to maintain or enhance a cognitive function in the healthy brain.

Brain-computer interfaces for basic science
abstract: Brain-computer interfaces (BCI) translate neural activity into movements of a computer cursor or robotic limb.  BCIs are known for their ability to assist paralyzed patients.  A lesser known, but increasingly important, use of BCIs is their ability to further our basic scientific understanding of brain function.  In particular, BCIs are providing insights into the neural mechanisms underlying sensorimotor control that are currently difficult to obtain using limb movements. In this talk, I will demonstrate how a BCI can be leveraged to study how the brain learns.  Specifically, I will address why learning some tasks is easier than others, as well as how populations of neurons change their activity in concert during learning.

title: Three Core Problems in the Modern DNN Theory of the Visual System, and Some Initial Steps Toward Solving To Them
abstract: The deep neural network theory of the ventral stream combines three core principles of modern artificial intelligence to build powerful brain-like models: network architectures (like hierarchical convolution) that build in evolutionarily reasonable priors, behavioral goals (like object categorization) that strongly constrain architectural parameters, and a learning rule (stochastic gradient descent) that robustly optimizes for these constraints. The confluence of these three principles has created models that make successful quantitative predictions of neural responses throughout the visual pathway.  However, in each of the three main areas, there are significant gaps between the theory and the observed biological data: in the architectural domain, the lack of recurrence and feedback; in the behavioral goal domain, the need for far too much labelled data; and in the learning rule, the need for non-local operations.  In this talk, I will describe recent work from my lab and that of collaborators taking steps toward resolving each of these three problems.

Rethinking boundary extension as a universal effect in scene memory
abstract: Boundary extension is a widely accepted psychological phenomenon in which observers will always extend the boundaries in their memory for a scene image. This phenomenon is thought to reflect a memory source error in which we mix visual inputs with our schema-based knowledge of the scene category, and has been taken to prove the roles of the hippocampus and parahippocampal cortex in the automatic extrapolation of scene schemas. However, studies on boundary extension have utilized a narrow set of stimuli, in which close-up objects are the central focus of the image. In a large-scale study re-examining boundary extension, we tested a boundary extension paradigm online with 2,000 participants, using 1,000 object- and scene-centric images representative of our visual experiences. We discover that the opposite effect of “boundary contraction” is just as prevalent, and is particularly common for the most scene-like images. In fact, we discover that visual features of the image are highly predictive of boundary transformation, in that images with few, close-up, central objects result in boundary extension, while more scene-like images with far views of several, distributed objects result in boundary contraction. We also replicate the effect of boundary contraction with in-lab participants performing an alternate memory drawing task. We further observe that both boundary extensions and contractions occur when participants are performing a perceptual task (copying an image), bringing to question whether these boundary transformations are even mnemonic in nature. These results debate boundary extension as a universal phenomenon reflecting scene schematization in memory, and suggest the strong sway of image features on one’s perception and memory of an image. Previous neuropsychological studies on boundary extension may have in fact recorded differences based on such image features (e.g., distance, size) rather than a mnemonic effect. Importantly, these results emphasize the importance of continuously revisiting accepted phenomena in the field, and the need to replicate effects across large, representative image sets and tasks.

title: Cholinergic Switch between Two Types of Slow Waves in Cerebral Cortex
abstract: Sleep slow waves are known to participate in memory consolidation, yet slow waves occurring under anesthesia present no positive effects on memory. Here, we shed light onto this paradox, based on a combination of extracellular recordings in vivo, in vitro, and computational models. We find two types of slow waves, based on analyzing the temporal patterns of successive slow-wave events. The first type is consistently observed in natural slow-wave sleep, while the second is shown to be ubiquitous under anesthesia. Network models of spiking neurons predict that the two slow wave types emerge due to a different gain on inhibitory versus excitatory cells and that different levels of spike-frequency adaptation in excitatory cells can account for dynamical distinctions between the two types. This prediction was tested in vitro by varying adaptation strength using an agonist of acetylcholine receptors, which demonstrated a neuromodulatory switch between the two types of slow waves. Finally, we show that the first type of slow-wave dynamics is more sensitive to external stimuli, which can explain how slow waves in sleep and anesthesia differentially affect memory consolidation, as well as provide a link between slow-wave dynamics and memory diseases.

title: Remember Matthew Taylor
abstract: Join us to remember Matthew Taylor. Matthew was a neuroscientist, communicator, and community manager at Numenta who sadly passed away on May 11th, 2020.
